prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation involves his girlfriend bringing a friend over to their apartment, and he's having issues with the friend's behavior and the girlfriend's change in demeanor.

First, the girlfriend initially came to stay because of a fight with her parents, and the author made it clear this was temporary. Now she's bringing her friend, which wasn't part of the original agreement. The author is uncomfortable with the friend's behavior—specifically, the friend being catty, making sarcastic comments, and the girlfriend acting more aggressively around her. There are instances where the friend laughs at the author's expense, dismisses his offer to make snacks, and the girlfriend becomes argumentative. The author also hears the friend and girlfriend complaining about him when he's nearby.

The author wants to tell the girlfriend not to bring the friend anymore. The question is whether he's in the wrong. 

Looking at the situation, the author provided specific examples of discomfort. The friend's behavior seems disrespectful, and the girlfriend changes her personality when the friend is around. Since the author's space in the apartment is being affected—his ability to relax and play games without being interrupted or criticized—he has a valid reason to be upset. The fact that the arrangement was supposed to be temporary adds to the issue; bringing friends might disrupt the temporary stay.

However, maybe the author should have communicated his discomfort earlier instead of letting things escalate. But considering the specific incidents, it's understandable he's frustrated. The girlfriend might need to be aware of how her friend's presence affects the author. The author isn't just being petty; he's addressing real behaviors that are making him uncomfortable in his own home. 

Since the girlfriend is acting differently around the friend, there might be underlying issues in their relationship. The author's request to stop the friend from coming over is about maintaining his own space and comfort, especially in a shared living situation. It's reasonable for him to set boundaries here. So, the answer might be B (not in the wrong). But wait, maybe the girlfriend's friend is just a different personality, and the author is overreacting? The examples given do seem significant, though. The friend's comments are outright rude, and the girlfriend's attitude is problematic. The author isn't wrong to want to address this. So, B makes sense.
